text: [Music]
it was um sort of um towards the end of
finishing the manuscript I had always
wanted to have um ordinary day or the
sense that the the ordinary life had
been interrupted in the title of the
book but um I couldn't really um come up
with something that it and I was uh
talking to U my book editor Clive prle
and we kept you know playing on how can
we put ordinary day and came up with
waiting for an ordinary day um and the
reason that I wanted um ordinary day is
because you know Iraqis as I say in the
book often tell you as soon as you say
you know what's going on how are you
feeling they say until now we're waiting
until now we're waiting um and it struck
me as uh well what are they waiting for
you know what what is it possibly that
they want
and I think it's just the return of
ordinary normal
life I think life was ordinary in terms
of the mundane uh daily things that make
up life it was definitely a lot more
secure you know you um Sadam was a
dictator there's no disputing that uh
but I think the Iraqis knew where the
red lines were if they didn't get
involved with politics or um with
activism they could have a day-to-day
normal life go to work come back you
know it wasn't great but it was wasn't
this um total catastrophe of not knowing
whether you're going to be alive if you
go to work uh which is which was kind of
the State of Affairs uh until recently
um so you know that's one of the things
the security is the number one issue the
other thing is infrastructure you know
um there's still about five or six hours
of electricity on average sometimes even
less than that um clean water is a very
big problem some irais are digging up
Wells uh in their backyards and trying
to manipulate the piping system to get
uh more air more more water sorry um and
so you know Municipal services like
picking up the garbage and sewitch
systems and these things are also um
very problematic
